title: Creating triangulation datasets
text: vignette demonstrates create triangulation dataset using triangulate package. manually construct small example dataset walk process preparing triangulation, including appending bias/indirectness values visualizing bias directions.

title: Creating triangulation datasets
text: define small dataset six studies, different combination bias/indirectness type direction.
code: example_data <- tibble(   result_id = paste0("S", 1:6),   study = paste("Study", 1:6),   yi = c(-.2, .25, -.1, -.3, .1, .3),   vi = round(runif(6, 0.01, 0.05), 3),   d1j = rep("moderate", 6),   d1t = c(rep("add", 2), rep("prop", 4)),   d1d = c("Favours comparator", "Favours experimental",           "Away from null", "Towards null",           "Away from null", "Towards null") )  example_data #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 7 #>   result_id study      yi    vi d1j      d1t   d1d                  #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>    <chr> <chr>                #> 1 S1        Study 1 -0.2  0.013 moderate add   Favours comparator   #> 2 S2        Study 2  0.25 0.043 moderate add   Favours experimental #> 3 S3        Study 3 -0.1  0.034 moderate prop  Away from null       #> 4 S4        Study 4 -0.3  0.016 moderate prop  Towards null         #> 5 S5        Study 5  0.1  0.01  moderate prop  Away from null       #> 6 S6        Study 6  0.3  0.029 moderate prop  Towards null

title: Creating triangulation datasets
text: Triangulation requires domain-level assessments long format. use tri_to_long() convert wide long form.
code: example_long <- tri_to_long(example_data) head(example_long) #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 8 #>   result_id study      yi    vi domain j        t     d                    #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <chr>    <chr> <chr>                #> 1 S1        Study 1 -0.2  0.013 d1     moderate add   favours comparator   #> 2 S2        Study 2  0.25 0.043 d1     moderate add   favours experimental #> 3 S3        Study 3 -0.1  0.034 d1     moderate prop  away from null       #> 4 S4        Study 4 -0.3  0.016 d1     moderate prop  towards null         #> 5 S5        Study 5  0.1  0.01  d1     moderate prop  away from null       #> 6 S6        Study 6  0.3  0.029 d1     moderate prop  towards null

title: Creating triangulation datasets
text: Calculate absolute direction bias/indirectness based type, direction, position estimate relative null.
code: example_abs <- tri_absolute_direction(example_long) head(example_abs) #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 8 #>   result_id study      yi    vi domain j        t     d     #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <chr>    <chr> <chr> #> 1 S1        Study 1 -0.2  0.013 d1     moderate add   right #> 2 S2        Study 2  0.25 0.043 d1     moderate add   left  #> 3 S3        Study 3 -0.1  0.034 d1     moderate prop  left  #> 4 S4        Study 4 -0.3  0.016 d1     moderate prop  right #> 5 S5        Study 5  0.1  0.01  d1     moderate prop  right #> 6 S6        Study 6  0.3  0.029 d1     moderate prop  left

title: Creating triangulation datasets
text: Next, append numerical prior values (mean SD) corresponding domain judgments using tri_append_bias().
code: example_bias <- tri_append_bias(example_abs, dat_bias_values) head(example_bias) #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 12 #>   result_id study      yi    vi domain j       t     d     bias_m_add bias_v_add #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <chr>   <chr> <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 S1        Study 1 -0.2  0.013 d1     modera‚Ä¶ add   right       0.09       0.05 #> 2 S2        Study 2  0.25 0.043 d1     modera‚Ä¶ add   left       -0.09       0.05 #> 3 S3        Study 3 -0.1  0.034 d1     modera‚Ä¶ prop  left        0          0    #> 4 S4        Study 4 -0.3  0.016 d1     modera‚Ä¶ prop  right       0          0    #> 5 S5        Study 5  0.1  0.01  d1     modera‚Ä¶ prop  right       0          0    #> 6 S6        Study 6  0.3  0.029 d1     modera‚Ä¶ prop  left        0          0    #> # ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: bias_m_prop <dbl>, bias_v_prop <dbl>

title: Absolute direction of bias/indirectness
text: first step adjustment calculate absolute direction bias/indirectness. helpful way understand . plotted standard forest plot. Note red arrows show absolute direction bias, direction adjustment.  additive bias/indirectness, position point estimate effect absolute direction bias. , regardless whether point estimate null, absolute direction bias/indirectness . contrast, proportional bias/indirectness, absolute direction bias depends position effect estimate. two scenarios consider:

title: Absolute direction of bias/indirectness
text: effect estimate null, bias towards null adjusted moving effect estimate proportionally left. Conversely, bias away null adjusted moving point estimate proportionally right.

what: Point estimate above NULL - Bias towards the NULL
title: Absolute direction of bias/indirectness
text: contrast, effect estimate null, bias towards null adjusted moving effect estimate proportionally left. Conversely, bias away null adjusted moving point estimate proportionally right. example, effect estimate represents protective effect (null), bias towards null adjusted moving effect estimate proportionally right. contrast, effect intervention harmful (effect estimate null), bias towards null adjusted moving effect estimate proportionally left.

title: Absolute direction of bias/indirectness
text: absolute direction also used defining sign prior tri_append_*() functions. bias/indirectness expected pull effect right (absolute direction = right), given positive sign. tri_calculate_adjusted_estimates(), subtracting total additive bias effect estimate yiy_i. correct absolute direction right, want sign prior positive (e.g.¬†N(0.9, 0.5)), subtracted effect estimate, overall impact negative (shift effect estimate left): yi‚àí(0.6)y_i - (0.6) = yi‚àí0.6y_i - 0.6 Conversely, assessment absolute direction bias left, want sign bias correction negative (e.g.¬†N(-0.9, 0.5)), shifting effect estimate right: yi‚àí(‚àí0.6)y_i - (-0.6) = yi+0.6y_i + 0.6 See Section 6.1 Turner et al. derivation equations.

title: Absolute direction of bias/indirectness
text: illustrate ensure code working correctly, lets consider simple dataset 6 studies, study fulfilling one scenarios described .
code: # Create the example dataset example_data <- tibble(   result_id = paste0("S", 1:6),  # <-- Add this line   study = paste("Study", 1:6),   yi = c(-.2, .25, -.1, -.3, .1, .3),   vi = round(runif(6, 0.01, 0.05), 3),  # use positive variances   d1j = rep("moderate", 6),   d1t = c(rep("add", 2), rep("prop", 4)),   d1d = c("Favours comparator", "Favours experimental",           "Away from null", "Towards null",           "Away from null", "Towards null") )   # Complete the preparation steps of triangulate example_data_prepped <- example_data %>%   tri_to_long() %>%   tri_absolute_direction() %>%   tri_append_bias(dat_bias_values)

what: Additive - Favours comparator - right - positive sign
title: Absolute direction of bias/indirectness
code: example_data[1,] #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 7 #>   result_id study      yi    vi d1j      d1t   d1d                #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>    <chr> <chr>              #> 1 S1        Study 1  -0.2 0.013 moderate add   Favours comparator example_data_prepped[1,] #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 12 #>   result_id study      yi    vi domain j       t     d     bias_m_add bias_v_add #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <chr>   <chr> <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 S1        Study 1  -0.2 0.013 d1     modera‚Ä¶ add   right       0.09       0.05 #> # ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: bias_m_prop <dbl>, bias_v_prop <dbl>

what: Additive - Favours intervention - left - negative sign
title: Absolute direction of bias/indirectness
code: example_data[2,] #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 7 #>   result_id study      yi    vi d1j      d1t   d1d                  #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>    <chr> <chr>                #> 1 S2        Study 2  0.25 0.043 moderate add   Favours experimental example_data_prepped[2,] #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 12 #>   result_id study      yi    vi domain j       t     d     bias_m_add bias_v_add #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <chr>   <chr> <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 S2        Study 2  0.25 0.043 d1     modera‚Ä¶ add   left       -0.09       0.05 #> # ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: bias_m_prop <dbl>, bias_v_prop <dbl>

what: Proportional - Point estimate above NULL - Towards the NULL - left - negative sign
title: Absolute direction of bias/indirectness
code: example_data[3,] #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 7 #>   result_id study      yi    vi d1j      d1t   d1d            #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>    <chr> <chr>          #> 1 S3        Study 3  -0.1 0.034 moderate prop  Away from null example_data_prepped[3,] #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 12 #>   result_id study      yi    vi domain j       t     d     bias_m_add bias_v_add #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <chr>   <chr> <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 S3        Study 3  -0.1 0.034 d1     modera‚Ä¶ prop  left           0          0 #> # ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: bias_m_prop <dbl>, bias_v_prop <dbl>

what: Proportional - Point estimate below NULL - Away from NULL - right - positive sign
title: Absolute direction of bias/indirectness
code: example_data[4,] #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 7 #>   result_id study      yi    vi d1j      d1t   d1d          #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>    <chr> <chr>        #> 1 S4        Study 4  -0.3 0.016 moderate prop  Towards null example_data_prepped[4,] #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 12 #>   result_id study      yi    vi domain j       t     d     bias_m_add bias_v_add #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <chr>   <chr> <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 S4        Study 4  -0.3 0.016 d1     modera‚Ä¶ prop  right          0          0 #> # ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: bias_m_prop <dbl>, bias_v_prop <dbl>

what: Proportional - Point estimate below NULL - Towards the NULL - right - positive sign
title: Absolute direction of bias/indirectness
code: example_data[5,] #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 7 #>   result_id study      yi    vi d1j      d1t   d1d            #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>    <chr> <chr>          #> 1 S5        Study 5   0.1  0.01 moderate prop  Away from null example_data_prepped[5,] #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 12 #>   result_id study      yi    vi domain j       t     d     bias_m_add bias_v_add #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <chr>   <chr> <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 S5        Study 5   0.1  0.01 d1     modera‚Ä¶ prop  right          0          0 #> # ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: bias_m_prop <dbl>, bias_v_prop <dbl>

title: Absolute direction of bias/indirectness
code: example_data[6,] #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 7 #>   result_id study      yi    vi d1j      d1t   d1d          #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>    <chr> <chr>        #> 1 S6        Study 6   0.3 0.029 moderate prop  Towards null example_data_prepped[6,] #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 12 #>   result_id study      yi    vi domain j       t     d     bias_m_add bias_v_add #>   <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <chr>   <chr> <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 S6        Study 6   0.3 0.029 d1     modera‚Ä¶ prop  left           0          0 #> # ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: bias_m_prop <dbl>, bias_v_prop <dbl>

title: Beta-carotene CHD triangulation example
text: tutorial demonstrates use triangulate package perform bias-adjusted meta-analysis association beta-carotene coronary heart disease (CHD), using estimates diverse study designs (randomised controlled trial (RCT), conventional observational study (Obs) Mendelian randomisation study(MR)).

title: Beta-carotene CHD triangulation example
text: Metadta_all_CHD dataset compiles results observational, randomised controlled trial (RCT), Mendelian randomisation (MR) studies examining association beta-carotene exposure coronary heart disease (CHD). includes standardised effect estimates (log risk ratios) standard errors, allowing dose-response meta-analysis across different study designs.
code: # Data loaded from: # ‚ÄúRes_MetaAll_beta_carotene_AllCHD_v2.Rdata‚Äù saved in the # R/CHD/01_Prep_Data.R directory of the GitHub repository: # https://github.com/CYShapland/BetaCarotene_CVD   load(system.file("extdata", "Res_MetaAll_beta_carotene_AllCHD_v2.Rdata", package = "triangulate"))

title: Beta-carotene CHD triangulation example
code: rob_file <- system.file("extdata", "beta_carotene_data.xlsx", package = "triangulate") RoB <- readxl::read_excel(rob_file, sheet = "main_data") colnames(RoB)[2] <- "Author"  Metadta_RoB_CHD<-merge(Metadta_all_CHD, RoB, by="Author")  # format to robviz colnames(Metadta_RoB_CHD)[which(colnames(Metadta_RoB_CHD)=="id")]<-"result_id" colnames(Metadta_RoB_CHD)[which(colnames(Metadta_RoB_CHD)=="Study")]<-"type" colnames(Metadta_RoB_CHD)[which(colnames(Metadta_RoB_CHD)=="Author")]<-"study" colnames(Metadta_RoB_CHD)[which(colnames(Metadta_RoB_CHD)=="logRR")]<-"yi" Metadta_RoB_CHD["vi"]<-Metadta_RoB_CHD["se_logRR"]^2  Metadta_RoB_CHD$study<-as.character(Metadta_RoB_CHD$study) Metadta_RoB_CHD$type<-as.character(Metadta_RoB_CHD$type) Metadta_RoB_CHD$Design<-as.character(Metadta_RoB_CHD$Design)  dat_CHDbias<-as_tibble(Metadta_RoB_CHD)

title: Beta-carotene CHD triangulation example
code: tri_dat_check(dat_CHDbias) #> tri_dat_check(): All expected columns are present (mode = 'minimal').  # Replace NA with "None" dat_CHDbias[is.na(dat_CHDbias)] <- "None"  # Convert to long bias format dat_CHDbias_rob <- dat_CHDbias %>%   tri_to_long() %>%   tri_absolute_direction() %>%   tri_to_wide()

what: 4. Add Indirectness & Adjust Effect Estimate for It
title: Beta-carotene CHD triangulation example
text: example, indirectness assumed missing (set ‚ÄúNone‚Äù) domains. However, real analyses, indirectness judgments can specified available. Also, tri_append_indirect() function appends indirectness priors also adjusts effect estimate accordingly ‚Äî therefore pipeline adjusts effect estimate bias indirectness.
code: dat_CHDind <- dat_CHDbias %>% select(result_id, study, type, yi, vi)  for (j in paste0("d", 1:3)) {   dat_CHDind[[paste0(j, "j")]] <- "None"   dat_CHDind[[paste0(j, "t")]] <- "None"   dat_CHDind[[paste0(j, "d")]] <- "None" }  # Convert to long and append dat_CHDind <- dat_CHDind %>%   tri_to_long() %>%   tri_absolute_direction() %>%   tri_append_indirect(triangulate::dat_ind_values)

previous_headings: 5. Apply Bias Priors & Estimate Adjusted Effects
title: Beta-carotene CHD triangulation example
text: triangulate::dat_bias_values object contains default priors domain judgment combination. step allows customize priors (e.g.¬†changing additive mean particular domain), building default set.
code: custom_bias_priors <- triangulate::dat_bias_values %>%   add_row(     domain = 'all', j = 'critical',     bias_m_add = 0.36, bias_v_add = 0.2,     bias_m_prop = 0.12, bias_v_prop = 0.064   )

previous_headings: 5. Apply Bias Priors & Estimate Adjusted Effects
what: 5.2 Append priors and prepare data, and estimate adjusted effects
title: Beta-carotene CHD triangulation example
code: dat_CHDbias_prep <- dat_CHDbias %>%   tri_to_long() %>%   tri_absolute_direction() %>%   tri_append_bias(custom_bias_priors)

what: 6. Final data adjusted for both bias and indirectness
title: Beta-carotene CHD triangulation example
code: datCHD_final <- tri_prep_data(dat_CHDbias_prep, dat_CHDind)

title: Beta-carotene CHD triangulation example
code: dat_CHDbias_final<-dat_CHDbias_rob %>% right_join(datCHD_final[c("result_id","yi_adj", "vi_adj")], by="result_id") # this data now contains original and adjusted estimates for plotting   png("beta_carotene_plot.png", width = 900, height = 700) tri_plot_bias_direction(dat_CHDbias_final) dev.off() #> agg_png  #>       2

title: Interactive Sensitivity Analysis
text: vignette demonstrates use interactive_bias_plot() function explore bias priors affect triangulated effect estimates real time using Shiny interface. function launches interactive app sliders control magnitude uncertainty additive proportional bias. adjusted effect estimates update automatically priors change.

title: Interactive Sensitivity Analysis
text: use small example dataset four hypothetical studies.
code: example_data <- tibble::tibble(   result_id = paste0("S", 1:4),   study = paste("Study", 1:4),   yi = c(-0.2, 0.25, -0.1, 0.15),   vi = c(0.02, 0.03, 0.015, 0.025),   type = "RCT" )

title: Interactive Sensitivity Analysis
text: run app, call function . open Shiny window (locally) allowing interactively adjust priors. üìå Note: command must run interactive R session (e.g., RStudio). won‚Äôt execute inside knitted document launch Shiny app run line--line.
code: interactive_bias_plot(example_data)

title: Interactive Sensitivity Analysis
text: tool useful exploring robust triangulated estimates different prior assumptions. can use data passing data frame columns: - result_id - study - type - yi (effect estimate) - vi (variance)

title: Sensitivity Analyses in Triangulate
text: article demonstrates conduct simple sensitivity analyses using triangulate package. explore changes bias priors influence resulting adjusted estimates, allowing us assess sensitive bias-adjusted results different assumptions. use manually-created, simplified version CHD dataset, examining different assumptions affect pooled results.

title: Sensitivity Analyses in Triangulate
text: define small synthetic dataset mimicking studies moderate bias indirectness.
code: # creates 4 made up study results with effect estimates (yi) and variances (vi)  example_data <- tibble(   result_id = paste0("S", 1:4),   study = paste("Study", 1:4),   yi = c(-0.2, 0.25, -0.1, 0.15),   vi = c(0.02, 0.03, 0.015, 0.025) )

what: Define Default Bias and Indirectness Priors
title: Sensitivity Analyses in Triangulate
text: apply ‚Äúmoderate‚Äù priors studies, similar base-case analysis.
code: # assumptions about additive and proportional bias, each with some uncertainty  bias_priors <- example_data %>%   mutate(     domain = "all",     j = "moderate",     bias_m_add = 0.1,     bias_v_add = 0.05,     bias_m_prop = 0.1,     bias_v_prop = 0.02,     type = "RCT"  # or whatever design you want   )    indirectness_priors <- tibble(   result_id = example_data$result_id,   domain = "all",   j = "moderate",   ind_m_add = 0.05,   ind_v_add = 0.03,   ind_m_prop = 0.05,   ind_v_prop = 0.02 )

title: Sensitivity Analyses in Triangulate
text: use tri_prep_data() tri_calculate_adjusted_estimates() get bias-adjusted effect sizes.
code: # this is where we combine the bias/indirectness priors with the study results and adjusts yi and vi to get new columns yi_adj and vi_adj for the adjusted estimate and varainces, respectively  base_prepped <- tri_prep_data(bias_priors, indirectness_priors) base_adjusted <- tri_calculate_adjusted_estimates(base_prepped)  base_adjusted %>%    select(result_id, yi, yi_adj, vi, vi_adj) #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 5 #>   result_id    yi   yi_adj    vi vi_adj #>   <chr>     <dbl>    <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 S1        -0.2  -0.300   0.02  0.0801 #> 2 S2         0.25  0.0795  0.03  0.0845 #> 3 S3        -0.1  -0.216   0.015 0.0749 #> 4 S4         0.15 -0.00490 0.025 0.0806

title: Sensitivity Analyses in Triangulate
text: now increase additive proportional bias priors simulate conservative scenario.
code: # represents a stricter assumption e.g if the bias was worse than originally thought. same process applied as before but with new priors  sensitive_bias <- bias_priors %>%   mutate(     bias_m_add = 0.2,     bias_v_add = 0.08,     bias_m_prop = 0.15,     bias_v_prop = 0.04 )  sensitive_prepped <- tri_prep_data(sensitive_bias, indirectness_priors) sensitive_adjusted <- tri_calculate_adjusted_estimates(sensitive_prepped)  sensitive_adjusted %>%   select(result_id, yi, yi_adj, vi, vi_adj) #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 5 #>   result_id    yi   yi_adj    vi vi_adj #>   <chr>     <dbl>    <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 S1        -0.2  -0.365   0.02  0.0977 #> 2 S2         0.25 -0.00736 0.03  0.0972 #> 3 S3        -0.1  -0.285   0.015 0.0917 #> 4 S4         0.15 -0.0868  0.025 0.0942

title: Sensitivity Analyses in Triangulate
text: plot adjusted effect estimates scenarios.
code: # overlays the 2 scenarios to visually represent how the priors affect the estimated effect comparison <- bind_rows(   base_adjusted %>% mutate(scenario = "Base"),   sensitive_adjusted %>% mutate(scenario = "Stricter Bias") ) %>%   mutate(result_id = factor(result_id, levels = paste0("S", 1:4)))  # or use your preferred order   ggplot(comparison, aes(y = result_id, x = yi_adj, color = scenario)) +   geom_point(position = position_dodge(0.4), size = 3) +   geom_errorbarh(     aes(xmin = yi_adj - sqrt(vi_adj), xmax = yi_adj + sqrt(vi_adj)),     height = 0.2,     position = position_dodge(0.4)   ) +   geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed") +   labs(     title = "Adjusted Estimates: Base vs. Stricter Bias Priors",     x = "Bias-Adjusted Effect",   # now horizontal axis     y = "Study"                   # now vertical axis   ) +   theme_minimal() #> Warning: `geom_errorbarh()` was deprecated in ggplot2 4.0.0. #> ‚Ñπ Please use the `orientation` argument of `geom_errorbar()` instead. #> This warning is displayed once every 8 hours. #> Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was #> generated. #> `height` was translated to `width`.

title: Sensitivity Analyses in Triangulate
text: vignette illustrates small changes prior assumptions can impact adjusted effect estimates. triangulate doesn‚Äôt yet include built-sensitivity function, process can easily scripted exploring model robustness. Note echo = FALSE parameter added code chunk prevent printing R code generated plot.

what: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: goal triangulate create generalised version bias-adjusted meta-analysis approach originally proposed Turner et al.¬† number steps process: Define causal question interest Identify relevant evidence sources standardise effect directions Specify idealised version study Assess extent direction bias/indirectness result Define modifying terms bias indirectness result Calculate bias-/indirectness-adjusted results perform meta-analysis package deals steps 5 6.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
code: devtools::install_github("mcguinlutriangulate")

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: WARNING #1: package development, API subject change point without warning. WARNING #2: approach described requires work preparation data work package. Please sure read documentation make use helper functions check whether data set-right. WARNING #3: approach described requires careful choice valid prior distributions bias/indirectness.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: approach described details create datasets, see Creating triangulation datasets vignette (construction). load data, helper functions convert long format convert absolute directions bias/indirectness. apply approach indirectness dataset:
code: # Load libraries library(magrittr) library(triangulate)  # See column names of dat_bias  colnames(dat_bias) #>  [1] "result_id" "study"     "type"      "yi"        "vi"        "d1j"       #>  [7] "d1t"       "d1d"       "d2j"       "d2t"       "d2d"       "d3j"       #> [13] "d3t"       "d3d"       "d4j"       "d4t"       "d4d"       "d5j"       #> [19] "d5t"       "d5d"       "d6j"       "d6t"       "d6d"       "d7j"       #> [25] "d7t"       "d7d"  head(dat_bias) #>   result_id   study type          yi         vi      d1j d1t #> 1   13401-2 Study 1 NRSI -0.12783337 0.12506586     High Add #> 2   14632-2 Study 2 NRSI -0.19845094 0.08680919 Moderate Add #> 3   14658-2 Study 3 NRSI -0.18632958 0.03361240     High Add #> 4   14665-6 Study 4 NRSI  0.19062036 0.05526578     High Add #> 5   14720-1 Study 5 NRSI -0.56211892 0.05141924     High Add #> 6   14761-1 Study 6 NRSI -0.09431068 0.06969822     High Add #>                    d1d      d2j  d2t                d2d      d3j  d3t #> 1   Favours comparator      Low None               None Moderate Prop #> 2 Favours experimental Moderate  Add Favours comparator      Low None #> 3   Favours comparator     High  Add Favours comparator      Low None #> 4   Favours comparator Moderate  Add      Unpredictable      Low None #> 5   Favours comparator      Low None               None      Low None #> 6   Favours comparator Moderate  Add Favours comparator      Low None #>             d3d d4j  d4t  d4d      d5j  d5t           d5d      d6j  d6t #> 1 Unpredictable Low None None      Low None          None      Low None #> 2          None Low None None      Low None          None Moderate  Add #> 3          None Low None None      Low None          None Moderate  Add #> 4          None Low None None      Low None          None      Low None #> 5          None Low None None Moderate Prop Unpredictable      Low None #> 6          None Low None None Moderate Prop Unpredictable      Low None #>             d6d      d7j  d7t            d7d #> 1          None Moderate Prop Away from null #> 2 Unpredictable Moderate Prop Away from null #> 3 Unpredictable Moderate Prop Away from null #> 4          None Moderate Prop Away from null #> 5          None Moderate Prop Away from null #> 6          None Moderate Prop Away from null  tri_dat_check(dat_bias) #> Looks good! #> All expected columns are present in the dataset. dat_bias <- triangulate::dat_bias %>%  # Convert to long format tri_to_long() %>%    tri_absolute_direction() %>%  tri_append_bias(triangulate::dat_bias_values) dat_ind <- triangulate::dat_ind %>% # Convert to long format tri_to_long() %>% tri_absolute_direction() %>% tri_append_indirect(triangulate::dat_ind_values)

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
code: dat_bias_values #>   domain        j bias_m_add bias_v_add bias_m_prop bias_v_prop #> 1    all     high       0.18       0.10        0.06       0.032 #> 2    all moderate       0.09       0.05        0.03       0.016 #> 3    all      low       0.00       0.00        0.00       0.000

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: now two clean datasets, one bias one indirectness, can use point, unadjusted (yi, vi) adjusted (yi_adj, vi_adj) estimates result. estimates can simply passed metafor analysis
code: dat_final <- tri_prep_data(dat_bias, dat_ind) #> Joining with `by = join_by(result_id)` #> Joining with `by = join_by(result_id)` #> Joining with `by = join_by(result_id)` #> Joining with `by = join_by(result_id)` model <- metafor::rma(   yi = yi,   vi = vi,   data = dat_final,   slab = dat_final$study,   method = 'DL' )  # Pass model to forest plot function metafor::forest(   model,   atransf = exp, ) model_adj <- metafor::rma(   yi = yi_adj,   vi = vi_adj,   data = dat_final,   slab = dat_final$study,   method = 'DL' )  # Pass model to forest plot function metafor::forest(   model_adj,   atransf = exp )

code: rob_direction(   dat,   sei = NULL,   title = NULL,   legend_cex = 0.9,   grouping = "type",   grouping_levels = c("MR", "NRSI", "Obs", "RCT"),   label_subgroup_summary = "RE Model for Subgroup",   rma_method = "REML",   ... )

title: Bias direction plots ‚Äî rob_direction
text: dat Dataframe sei Vector containing corresponding standard errors (normally defined column within dataset, .e. dat$sei). Note: either vi sei must set. title Graph title legend_cex Expansion factor figure legend. grouping Variable provided dataset resulting plot stratified. Often study design overall risk--bias level. grouping_levels Ordering grouping variable. Note: levels plotted order, starting bottom graph (.e. last item vector placed top graph) label_subgroup_summary Annotation text subgroup label ... arguments pass metafor::forest
